legislation.statute: Nevada's original RPS was established in 1997. Most recently updated in 2009, investor-owned utilities and  retail suppliers will be required to acheive 25% of retail sales from renewable sources by 2025.  New energy efficiency measures count toward the goal. Nevada statute also requires the retirement of 800 MW of coal plants,  to be replaced with cleaner sources (including at minimum 350 MW from renewable sources). The RPS is administered by the  Public Utilities Commission of Nevada.

rps_tech_details.name: Eligible Technologies
rps_tech_details.description: Solar Water Heat, Solar Space Heat, Solar Thermal Electric, Solar Thermal Process Heat, Photovoltaics,  Landfill Gas, Wind, Biomass, Hydroelectric, Geothermal Electric, Municipal Solid Waste, Waste Tires  (using microwave reduction), Energy Recovery Processes, Solar Pool Heating, Anaerobic Digestion, Biodiesel,  Geothermal Direct-Use

rps_tech_details.name: Geographic Eligibility
rps_tech_details.description: Only energy produced in Nevada or delivered to Nevada applies toward the RPS goal

rps_tech_details.name: Technology Requirements
rps_tech_details.description: Through 2015, 5% of the annual RPS requirement (1.2% of sales in 2015) must be fulfilled through solar. For the period 2016 to 2025, it rises to 6% of generation (1.5% of sales in 2025)

rps_tech_details.name: Penalty
rps_tech_details.description: According to the legislation, state regulators may impose penalties, but none have been specified to date.

legislation.cost_cap_details:
No explicit cost cap exists. All new contracts must be approved by the PUC. If insufficient supply is available at  just and reasonable terms (as determined by the PUC), then the PUC may choose to exempt the provider  from remaining RPS requirements

overview: 25% of the state's energy consumption must be from renewable sources by 2025
snapshot.policy_trajectory: Most states define a pathway to 'ramp-up' the amount of renewable energy that must be sold. This chart allows you to compare your state's policy pathway to its neighbors. Nevada's pathway is red. Click on another state to learn more about their RPS.
snapshot.summary: Nevada's Renewable Portfolio Standard (RPS) establishes a minimum amount of renewable energy that must be sold by the state's electricity providers. This page identifies and describes the features of the RPS and how they work together to define the minimum amount of renewable energy that will be sold in Nevada.
